EXISTING STRUCTURES
─────────────────────────────
### Shared Smelting Furnaces Automation Network
Consists of:
• Stone Furnace at Position(x=0.0, y=0.0) paired with burner inserters and output chests to process raw ores into plates.
• Stone Furnace at Position(x=5.0, y=0.0) similarly configured.

### Iron Ore Mining Automation Setup
Consists of:
• A burner‐mining drill connected to a wooden chest and interlinked by transport belts for extracting and collecting iron ore.

### Automation Research Lab
Consists of:
• A laboratory receiving automation‐science-pack inputs and supported by a network of small electric poles to maintain power.

### Water Supply System for Power Generation with Updated Steam Engine Placement
Consists of:
• A Boiler at Position(x=8.0, y=20.5) with connection points at Position(x=8.5, y=18.5) and Position(x=8.5, y=22.5); its fluid box holds 200 units of water.
• An Offshore Pump at Position(x=0.5, y=30.5).
• Pre‐existing Steam Engines at Positions: (1.5, 13.5), (13.5, 14.5), (19.5, 14.5), (13.5, 17.5), (17.5, 20.5), (11.5, 20.5) and (22.5, 18.5).
• An additional steam engine was previously crafted and placed at Position(x=4.5, y=23.5) but remains unconnected via pipes.
• Recent execution steps (Steps 416–423) have focused on obtaining and positioning an extra steam engine intended for improved integration with the Boiler. One steam engine was successfully crafted (Step 418) and initially placed at Position(x=8.5, y=17.5); however, multiple pipe connection attempts from the Boiler failed. Subsequent manual repositioning efforts—aiming for Position(x=8.5, y=21.0)—also encountered placement failures (either due to absence in inventory or due to target area obstructions), leaving the new engine’s integration unresolved.

ERROR TIPS
────────────
• Crafting Failures for Steam Engines
 – Ensure all required sub‐ingredients (such as iron plates and iron-gear-wheels) are available before commencing a steam engine craft. Verify that production chains and inventory levels for these intermediate items are sufficient to meet recipe demands.
  
• Pipe Connection Failures
 – When errors occur during pipe connections (e.g. failure to connect the Boiler at Position(x=8.0, y=20.5) with a nearby steam engine), check that both entities’ connection points are clear, aligned, and within the allowable range. Also confirm that the pipe inventory is adequate and the surrounding area is free of obstructions.

• Manual Placement and Repositioning Errors
 – Before issuing manual placement commands, verify that the targeted steam engine is present in the inventory and that the designated area is unoccupied. Obstructions or pre‐existing objects at the target coordinates can prevent successful placement.

• Null Object and Attribute Errors in Connection Calculations
 – Errors such as "'NoneType' object has no attribute 'position'" indicate that an expected entity or its attribute is missing or uninitialized. Ensure that all relevant entity objects have been properly instantiated and that their positional data is valid prior to calculating pipe routing or connection requirements.
